Course_Description:
Abstract:
This lecture covers the fundamentals of photorealistic and interactive image synthesis. We focus on techniques to achieve interactive frame rates for realistic rendering of complex models and scenes using GPU acceleration. Key graphics algorithms and their efficient implementation via graphics APIs will be demonstrated. We will explore dedicated parts of the graphics pipeline, reviewing the functionality of consumer-class graphics accelerators, including programmable vertex, geometry, and fragment shaders. Additionally, we will discuss the governing equations of physics-based light transport and demonstrate effective solution methods for simulating global illumination. Topics include:

Interactive image synthesis
Graphics APIs & hardware, OpenGL, DirectX, Vulkan and Metal
Fixed function & programmable graphics pipeline
Introduction to General-purpose computation on graphics hardware (GPGPU)
Lighting
Local lighting models
GPU implementation
Environment mapping
GPU shadowing techniques
Projective shadows
Shadow volumes
Shadow Maps
Transparent Objects:
(depth) sorting with implementations on graphics hardware
Order independent transparency & depth peeling on GPUs
Physics based rendering
Radiometric quantities, rendering equation
Ray tracing / path tracing
radiosity
Irradiance volumes
Precomputed radiance transfer (PRT)
Ambient Occlusion with focus on GPU-based interactive methods
Special topics:
GPU friendly high quality terrain rendering & synthesis
Rendering of fur and hair
Scenegraph APIs
Acceleration structures and culling techniques
Human visual perception and high dynamic range imaging (HDRI)
REYES
Image compression techniques
Cloud computing, web applications and mobile applications.

Fundamental concepts and protocols for distributed systems.

The lecture begins with the basics of distributed communication:

Serialization (ASN.1, CORBA XDR, SOAP)
Remote Procedure Calls
Distributed Objects

It then focuses on important foundational algorithms:

Physical Clocks
Logical Clocks
Transactions
Synchronization
Replication and Consistency
Global State

Learning Analytics has attracted a great deal of attention as practitioners, institutions, and researchers are increasingly seeing the potential that LA has to shape the future technology-enhanced learning landscape. LA is an emerging data science field that represents the application of big data and analytics in education. It deals with the development of methods that harness educational data sets to support the learning process. LA is an interdisciplinary field involving competences from computer science, cognitive psychology, and pedagogy. It leverages various computer science methods. These include statistics, big data, machine learning, data/text mining, information visualization, visual analytics, and recommender systems. The first part of the course will provide a systematic overview on this emerging field and its key concepts through a reference model for LA based on four dimensions, namely data, environments, context (what?), stakeholders (who?), objectives (why?), and methods (how?). In the second part of this courses, we will discuss various methods and techniques required to develop innovative LA systems, in relation to each dimension of the LA reference model. In the last part of the course, current topics and trends in LA research will be presented and discussed in invited talks. The presented methods and technologies will be further investigated and applied in small student projects carried out throughout the course. The course topics will include:

Learning analytics and related areas (e.g. educational data mining)
A reference model for learning analytics
Big Data (Hadoop ecosystem)
Learner modeling
Ethics and privacy in learning analytics
Assessment and feedback
Machine Learning / Data Mining (classification, clustering, association rule mining)
Recommender systems
Information visualisation and visual analytics
Social Network Analysis
Current topics in learning analytics (invited lectures)

Concurrent systems – of which distributed systems are a special case – are often difficult for a user or programmer to fully understand. Even relatively small systems, consisting of multiple interacting components, can exhibit very complex behavior. Additionally, one encounters phenomena and problems (deadlocks, mutual exclusion) that cannot occur in sequential systems. Therefore, this lecture will cover relevant modeling techniques and analysis methods to improve the understanding of such systems. The following topics are expected to be covered:

- Transition systems
- Behavioral equivalences: language equivalence, bisimulation
- Process calculi – CCS
- Petri nets (partial order techniques)
- Graph transformation systems

Hot topics and the state-of-the-art in digital games research. We will examine digital games from the different perspectives of game design research, social and media psychology. Further, we dive into new technological advances and trends in computer entertainment. Digital Games Research complements the master's lecture Game Architecture and Design which focuses on the practical parts of designing and developing digital games. However, this lecture provides insight into research about and with digital games. Both courses are independent of each other.

Our course concept is in line with the basic steps of scientific work in the domain of computer entertainment research. We will run through the process of the preparation and submission of a scientific paper to a course internal conference where the respective publications will be presented orally.

The World Wide Web and its underlying technologies are increasingly gaining importance for the development of interactive Web applications. This course introduces concepts, principles, and methods in current client and server-side Web technologies. Basic Web technologies such as HTML, CSS, JSON, JavaScript, etc. are a prerequisite to take this course. The focus of this course is rather on advanced topics in emerging Web technologies. These include extensions of Web standards, Web toolkits and development environments, current backend Web frameworks (e.g. Node/Express, Flask), frontend Web frameworks (e.g. Angular, React), and combination of different Web technologies (e.g. MEAN/MERN Stack, Dash). This course follows a student-centered and project-based learning approach. Web technologies will be presented in the lecture by student groups. The presented technologies are further investigated and applied in hands-on sessions as well as small student projects carried out throughout the course.

Prerequisites:
- Knowledge of basic Web technologies such as HTML, CSS, and JavaScript is required
- Knowledge of Python is helpful
- High motivation and commitment
- Good teamwork skills

Introductory course to Computer Graphics. The course teaches the algorithms used to program a computer to generate images of geometric models with associated appearance properties. Starting with introductory lectures on the basics of surfaces and light propagation, the course will focus on the two well-known rendering methods, CPU and GPU-based ray-tracing and GPU-accelerated raster graphics. Topics include:

Basics
Geometric Models: Meshes, Implicit Surfaces, Splines
Color & Perception
Light Transport
3D Image Generation Methods
OpenGL, DirectX, CUDA
Ray Tracing I: basics
Ray Tracing II: acceleration techniques
Fast Intersection Tests
Space Partitioning & Bounding Volume Hierarchies
GPU-acceleration
Rasterization & GPU-based rendering
Linear and Affine Transformations
Rasterization and Shading
Clipping
Visibility & Shadows
Curves & surfaces
Sampling Theory

Fundamentals of both topics, Game Architecture and Game Design, form the content of the lecture. Beyond that, an insight into the processes and proceedings of the games industry is given.
The learnt knowledge can be applied to the prototypic implementation of one’s own game project, which will be produced with Unity3D.
The topics of the lecture contain the following thematic priorities:

Game Production and Project Engineering
Theoretical foundations of Game Design
Game Interface Design
Gameplay and Game Balance
Interactive Storytelling and Character Development

Please note that the attendance is limited to 25 participants.

Requirements:
- Basic programming skills
- Willingness to become acquainted with new application development systems

Fundamental concepts and techniques in Information Retrieval, focusing on the efficient organization and retrieval of information from large-scale data. Students will explore topics such as search engine fundamentals, indexing, ranking algorithms, natural language processing for search, and performance evaluation. Practical applications, including web search and recommendation systems, will be emphasized, and students will work with real-world datasets to develop and refine IR systems. The course also covers key issues like information retrieval models, query formulation, and relevance feedback.

Computers and ‘machine-intelligence’ are frequently discussed as the means for addressing today’s critical educational challenges: learning remotely, learning at one’s own pace, learning according to one’s needs and background, providing quality education to all and for all. In this course, we welcome all master-level students with technical or non-technical backgrounds. Through the semester, we will cover topics on the intersection of Artificial Intelligence in Education, Educational Technologies, and Human-Computer Interaction, and we will carry out hands-on exercises to deepen our understanding of intelligent learning technologies.

Advanced topics on understanding, designing, and evaluating interactive systems. After completing the lecture, students understand the characteristics of interactive systems, they know contemporary areas of interactive systems and how to act in these areas, and they know how to do applied research in these areas. Besides other topics, the lecture will cover these areas:

Information Visualization
Tangible and natural user interfaces
Augmented Reality
Human-Robot Interaction
Research Methods in Interactive Systems
Theories and analysis frameworks for Interactive Systems
Designing Interactive Systems
Course_Teacher:
Prof. Dr-Ing. Michael Prilla
 Dr. Sebastian Büttner

Course_Name: Internet of Things: Protocols and System Software
Course_Description:
This master's course provides an introduction to the field of the 'Internet of Things' (IoT), where billions of embedded systems (sensors, actuators) continuously make data about the real world available on the Internet in real-time.

Topics covered include: IoT system architectures (Cloud vs Edge vs Mesh), communication protocols (IEEE 802.15.4, NbIoT, 6LoWPAN, MQTT), update protocols, data modeling, data access (Stream Processing, Complex Event Processing), and data processing with machine learning techniques for IoT devices (Pruning, Quantization). In addition to theoretical knowledge, practical programming of IoT systems will also be taught in the lab, e.g., using Arduino devices, sensors, Raspberry Pis, and freely selectable cloud-based IoT platforms.

Course_Name: Lineare und Diskrete Optimierung mit Anwendungen auf Graphen

Course_Description:
For the automatic verification and validation of programs and systems, methods are required that, when given a program and its associated specification, can decide whether the program fulfills this specification.

In general, this problem is undecidable, but there are many safety-critical programs that we would still like to analyze and verify automatically. These can be analyzed if we allow non-complete methods. The requirement is that these analysis methods never consider a faulty program as correct, although rejecting correct programs is permissible (one-sided error). In this way, a large number of programs can still be analyzed, and their correctness verified. Another important application area is program optimization in compiler construction.

The lecture will particularly cover the following topics:

- Data flow analysis (Fixed-point theory, Monotone frameworks, Worklist algorithm, Application examples: Compiler construction, Java Bytecode Verifier)
- Basics of abstract interpretation (Galois connections, Safe approximation of functions, Abstraction refinement)

Tools
The following tools will be used in the lecture:

- PAG/WWW (Program analysis generator with WWW interface)
- jasmin (Assembler for Java bytecode)

The focus of this introductory course is on discussing efficient techniques to visually represent large-scale data sets from simulation and measurement. Starting with a brief introduction on the data generation processes, the visualization pipeline, data structures, mapping techniques, and special rendering techniques for scientific data will be discussed. Various examples will be given to outline the benefits of visualization techniques in practical applications. A particular focus is put on interactive methods using GPU-based techniques. Topics include:

- History of Visualization Methods, from ancient wall paintings to GPU accelerated rendering
- Data Sources
- Simulation: basics of finite element discretization to GPU-based methods
- Measurements: physical details of computed tomography to accelerated reconstruction
- Data Representation: interpolation techniques, from data to meshes
- Filtering: various filtering methods and their hardware acceleration
- Scalar Volumes
- The basics of direct volume rendering
- GPU accelerated volume rendering I: slicing and ray-casting
- GPU accelerated volume rendering II: ray guided volume rendering and out-of-core techniques
- Indirect volume rendering
- Unstructured data
- Flow Visualization
- Glyph based methods
- Geometric methods
- GPU-based particle tracing
- Texture-based methods I: LIC
- Texture-based methods II: Explicit Frequency Control
- Feature based methods
- Visualization methods for Virtual Reality
To understand and to design compilers and interpreters, and to show them the practical problems of compiler construction.

The lecture teaches students how to design and evaluate systems that help humans to cooperate and collaborate with each other. It provides an overview of the research area Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW). After completing the module, the students have learned principles of designing CSCW systems and know the most important technical methods for supporting social interaction. They are able to critically discuss CSCW systems as well as to design and evaluate them.

In particular, the lecture covers these and more topics:

- Basics of human communication, cooperation, and coordination
- Paradigms and concepts of computer-mediated group work
- Case studies for IT support of cooperative work
- Specific cooperation support such as Social Media, Augmented Reality, Meeting Support
- Analysis and Design of User Interfaces for Groupware
- Introduction and evaluation of CSCW systems
- Practical application of lecture contents in accompanying project tasks
